questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with chronic burning pain, numbness, and tingling on the right side of her body not relieved with NSAIDs. The symptoms began 2 months after she suffered a stroke. On examination, she has hyperesthesia and allodynia on the right side. The clinician suspected it to be due to lacunar infarct. What could be the likely site of infarct causing her present symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Ventroposterolateral thalamus

 

Explanation:

Chronic burning pain not relieved by usual NSAIDs following a stroke is due to lacunar infarct of Ventroposterolateral Thalamus, known as Dejerine-Roussy syndrome (aka) Thalamic pain syndrome.

 

Dejerine Roussy syndrome:

Cause
  • Lacunar infarct of penetrating branches of PCA (P1 segment)

Clinical features
  • Hemianesthesia affecting one half of body (initially) [Hemisensory loss]
  • Later causing burning pain sensation (during recovery)
  • O/E: Hyperaesthesia, allodynia may be present on the affected side

Treatment
  • Carbamazepine, Gabapentin, TCAs (Tricyclic antidepressants)

 

Small vessel stroke:

Cause
  • Lacunar infarct (affecting penetrating branches) secondary to atherosclerotic occlusion/lipohyalinosis

Risk factors
  • Hypertension: Most common
  • Diabetes
  • Atrial fibrillation
  • Smoking
  • Hyperlipidemia

Sites & manifestations
  • Posterior limb of internal capsule (Option B)
  • Pure motor hemiparesis
  • Genu of internal capsule (Option C)
  • Clumsy hand dysarthria lacunar syndrome (facial weakness)
  • Cortical pontocerebellar tract (Option D)
  • I/L ataxia + C/L hemiparesis
  • Ventroposterolateral thalamus (Option A)
  • Dejerine-Roussy syndrome

questions.text: An elderly patient presented with a history of slowing of movements, frequent falls and forgetfulness. MRI done is as shown below. Which among the following is not a feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Resting tremors

 

Explanation:

MRI shows Hummingbird sign - suggestive of Progressive supranuclear palsy [PSP] (a Parkinson-plus disorder). Tremors are not a feature of PSP.

 

Progressive supranuclear palsy [PSP]
  • Early onset postural instability - H/O frequent falls + Dementia
  • Tremors - absent (Option B)
  • Defective downward gaze (Option A) + extended posture of body
  • Dystonia: Procerus sign (forehead) + Gunslinger’s gait (flexion at elbow & adduction at upper limb) (Option D)
  • Poor response to levodopa (Option C)
  • MRI: Hummingbird sign

Lewy body dementia [LBD]
  • Parkinsonian features + Visual hallucination + early Dementia
  • Associated REM sleep disorder may be present

Multiple systemic atrophy [MSA]
  • MSA-A: Autonomic instability + (orthostatic hypotension)
  • MSA-C: Cerebellar symptoms + ; MRI- Hot cross bun sign (Pons)

 

Corticobasal syndrome [CBS]
  • Dystonia + myoclonus + alien limb phenomena present alone with other parkinsonian features

questions.text: Which of the following clinical signs of upper motor neuron lesion is described correctly ?

choices.text: Babinski’s sign - Lateral stroke of the sole resulting in flexion of all toes
Gordon’s sign - A stroke beneath and in front of the lateral malleolus causing an extensor plantar response.
Oppenheim’s sign - Apply pressure along the medial aspect of tibia causing an extensor plantar response
Chaddock’s sign - Squeeze the calf muscles to produce extensor plantar response.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Oppenheim’s sign - Apply pressure along the medial aspect of tibia causing an extensor plantar response.

 

Explanation:

  • Oppenheim’s sign is elicited by applying pressure along the medial aspect of tibia to cause an extensor plantar response i.e. dorsiflexion of the great toe and fanning of the other toes. 
  • Babinski’s sign is elicited by stroking the lateral aspect of the sole from the heel towards the little toe and then continuing up to the great toe. This results in an extensor plantar response as described above in a case of upper motor neuron lesion. Flexion of all toes indicates a normal person or the presence of a lower motor neuron lesion. 
  • Gordon’s sign is elicited by squeezing the calf muscles to produce an extensor plantar response.
  • Chaddock’s sign is elicited by stimulating the dorsolateral aspect of the foot from the posterior portion of the skin just beneath the lateral malleolus anteriorly and along the external edge of the foot.

questions.text: A 5 year old female child presented to the casualty with recurrent seizures and left sided hemiplegia. On physical examination, a reddish skin lesion was found since birth over the right side of her forehead involving the right eye, nose and cheek. On CT imaging of the brain, the following picture was seen. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Sturge Weber syndrome

 

Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario of a 5 year old female child with complaints of recurrent seizures, left sided hemiplegia with a description of port-wine stain in the right ophthalmic division of trigeminal nerve and a CT image showing the classical tram-track or rail-road sign suggests a diagnosis of Sturge Weber syndrome.
  • It is a sporadic disorder neurocutaneous syndrome characterised by a facial nevus or ‘port wine stain’ in the distribution of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve along with an ipsilateral ‘rail road pattern/tram-track’ of intracranial parallel cortical calcification and glaucoma.
  • The major clinical manifestations include contralateral hemiplegia and intractable focal seizures which may lead to intellectual disability. Control of seizures may require surgery.

Regular eye evaluation is necessary to monitor for glaucoma.

Von-Hippel Lindau syndrome (Option A):

  • Mutations (3p deletion) lead to numerous vascular tumours in the body such as clear cell carcinoma of the kidneys, cerebellar and retinal hemangioblastomas and spinal cord angiomas.
  • Cerebellar signs and raised intracranial tension are the usual manifestations.

 

Neurofibromatosis (Option C):

  • This is the most common type of neurocutaneous syndrome.
  • There are two types: NF1 or von Recklinghausen disease caused by deletion of NF1 on chromosome 17, and NF2 (central NF), with NF2 located on chromosome 22.
  • They also present with recurrent seizures but instead of port-wine stain, they show neurofibromas with nervous system abnormalities of optic glioma, intraspinal neurofibroma, aqueductal stenosis and dural ectasia.

 

Ataxia telangiectasia (Option D):

  • It usually presents with slowly progressive truncal ataxia starting in infancy.
  • Choreoathetosis and oculomotor apraxia are usually seen.
  • Skin manifestations start after the age of 2-3 years with cutaneous (at flexures) and ocular (bulbar conjunctiva) telangiectasia.
  • In addition, there is an immunodeficiency component leading to frequent sino-pulmonary infections and risk of lymphoreticular malignancies.

questions.text: A 15 year old adolescent male patient came with his parents with complaints of neuropsychiatric symptoms such as tremors and an irritable mood. On physical examination, stigmata of liver disease and the following ophthalmological finding is seen. Which of the following is correct about this condition?

choices.text: Defect in P type ATP ase ATP7B protein
Defect in P type ATP ase ATP7A protein
ATP7B gene defect with increased ceruloplasmin
ATP7A gene defect with increased ceruloplasmin

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Defect in P type ATP ase protein due to ATP7B gene defect

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario of an adolescent male with neuropsychiatric symptoms, hepatomegaly and ophthalmological finding of Kayser-Fleischer ring is suggestive of Wilson’s disease.  The gene involved is ATP7B gene on chromosome 13. (ATP 7A In menke kinky hair disease). The protein whose functioning is defective in Wilson disease is P type ATP ase ATP7B protein in liver that is responsible for hepatobiliary excretion of copper and incorporation into ceruloplasmin. Due to this defect copper will accumulate in liver and other body tissue.

Option C is wrong as it says increased ceruloplasmin. 

 

Wilson’s disease

Description

Wilson's disease is caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, leading to defective copper excretion ( P type ATP ase ) functioning is reduced and increased copper accumulation in organs such as the liver, brain, and eyes, resulting in hepatolenticular degeneration.

Clinical features
  • Hepatic: Jaundice, hepatomegaly, ascites; chronic liver disease may develop by age 40.
  • Neurological: Dysarthria, rigidity, tremors, uncoordinated handwriting.
  • Psychiatric: Personality changes such as irritable mood, depression and anxiety.
  • Ocular: Kayser-Fleischer rings (copper deposits in the Descemet’s membrane of cornea) and sunflower cataracts.
  • Other: Delayed puberty, renal tubular dysfunction, skeletal issues (osteoporosis, rickets), hemolytic anemia.

Investigations

  • Biochemical: Low serum copper and ceruloplasmin, elevated hepatic transaminases, aminoaciduria, hemolytic anemia.
  • Diagnostic Tests: Increased urinary copper excretion; liver biopsy for hepatic copper measurement (values >200 μg/g dry weight is definitive of Wilson’s disease).

Treatment

  • Copper Chelation: Trientine is preffered first line drug 
  • Zinc Therapy: Reduces copper absorption in the gut mainly useful for presymptomatic patients and during pregnancy.
  • Liver Transplantation: Considered in advanced cases or when medical therapy fails.

 

Hemochromatosis (Option B):

  • Excessive iron absorption and deposition mainly in the liver, pancreas and heart tissues, leading to organ damage and failure.
  • Clinical features include liver cirrhosis, diabetes, skin pigmentation (bronze diabetes), arthritis, cardiomyopathy, and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

 

Gilbert syndrome (Option C):

  • Most patients are asymptomatic but may experience chronic or recurrent jaundice, often triggered by illness, fasting, or stress.
  • Mild symptoms like fatigue, nausea, anorexia, or abdominal pain may occur, but other liver functions remain normal.

 

Classical galactosemia (Option D):

Untreated infants may face severe complications like cataracts, intellectual disability, and renal dysfunction, while even treated individuals can experience growth and developmental issues.

questions.text: A 30 year old male patient was brought to the ER with a history of RTA and sustained multiple injuries. On primary assessment, he was disoriented and complained of  severe headache. Meningeal signs are noted. On neuroimaging the following image was seen. What is the most probable diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Subarachnoid haemorrhage

 

Explanation:

CT brain shows hyperdensities in bilateral sylvian cisterns and the basal cisterns producing star of death appearance. The combination of CT findings and headache with nuchal rigidity implies subarachnoid hemorrhage. Most common cause of SAH is trauma.

questions.text: A 75 year old male patient came to the OPD with complaints of recent onset stooping, broad based abnormal gait, short-term memory loss and urge incontinence. On radiological investigation, the following image is obtained. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Normal pressure hydrocephalus

 

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario of an elderly male patient with complaints of recent onset stooping, broad based abnormal gait (gait apraxia/ gait instability), short term memory loss (dementia) and urge incontinence and on radiological investigation the image shows bilateral lateral ventriculomegaly which is suggestive of normal pressure hydrocephalus.

 

Normal pressure hydrocephalus

  • It is also called Hakims–Adams syndrome which is seen usually in the elderly above 60 years of age with the classical triad of urinary incontinence, dementia and gait instability (wet,wacky and wobbly).
  • Shuffling gait with preserved arm swing in NPH (Arm swing lost in Parkinsonism)
  • Other key features include bilateral ventriculomegaly and usually a normal CSF (6-28 cm of H2O) opening pressure although can be increased in some cases.
  • Treatment includes shunt procedures such as ventriculo-peritoneal shunting.

 

Parkinson’s disease (Option A): Although there is presence of a stooping gait in this case it does not denote a classical festinant gait seen in Parkinsonism. Other key features such as rigidity and tremors which are characteristic of Parkinson’s disease are also absent. Dementia in a case of Parkinson’s disease occurs usually after more than 1 year of Parkinson’s disease manifestations.

 

Alzheimer’s disease (Option B): It is the most common cause of dementia which is usually inherited due to defective ubiquitin protein which helps in targeting and degradation of damaged neuronal protein. Another mechanism involved in the disease is due to decreased acetylcholine levels in the brain neurotransmission. Although short term memory loss is associated with Alzheimer’s; other clinical features and radiological imaging rules out its possible diagnosis.

 

Idiopathic intracranial hypertension (Option D):

 

Idiopathic intracranial hypertension

Pathophysiology

  • It usually affects young obese women. Its exact cause is uncertain, but obesity may impair CSF reabsorption, while certain medications like tetracycline and vitamin A are associated.

Clinical features

  • Patients typically present with headaches, diplopia, and transient visual disturbances.
  • Physical signs include papilloedema and possible sixth cranial nerve palsy.

Investigations

  • Brain imaging to rule out structural causes.
  • Lumbar puncture, revealing elevated CSF pressure > 30 cmH2O.

Treatment

  • Weight loss might be beneficial.
  • Medications such as acetazolamide or topiramate may lower intracranial pressure.
  • Repeated lumbar punctures can alleviate headaches, but if vision is threatened, surgical options like optic nerve sheath fenestration or a lumbo-peritoneal shunt may be necessary.

questions.text: A 13 year old male patient presented with complaints of poor scholastic performance, history of recurrent seizures since infancy and the following incidental finding on his back. What does the incidental finding denote and probable diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer : C) Shagreen patch and Tuberous sclerosis

 

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario of an adolescent male patient with complaints of poor scholastic performance (low IQ), history of recurrent seizures since infancy and clinical image showing shagreen patch suggests diagnosis of tuberous sclerosis. Adenoma sebaceium is seen on face and is ruled out. Cafe au lait macules would be light brown in color and seen in NF-1 where small potato like growth would be seen. 
 

Tuberous sclerosis (BOURNEVILLE DISEASE)

Pathophysiology

  • It is an autosomal dominant disorder.
  • Genes involved are TSC1 in chromosome 9 producing hamartin protein and TSC2 is on chromosome 16 producing tuberin protein.
  • Both these proteins play a role in cell growth and cell division. Mutations lead to aberrant activation of mTOR pathway signalling giving rise to various tumours.

Clinical features

  • Classical triad of seizures (epilepsy), low IQ, facial angiofibromas (adenoma sebaceum)- EPILOIA
  • Other skin manifestations include shagreen patches, hypomelanotic macules (Ash leaf macules), periungual fibromas (Koenen tumours)
  • Associated with renal angiomyolipomas, cardiac rhabdomyomas (in children)
  • Increased risk of subependymal nodules, cortical tubers and subependymal giant cell astrocytomas (SEGAs)

Treatment

  • Anticonvulsants for seizures
  • mTOR inhibitors (sirolimus or everolimus) for SEGAs and seizure reduction

 

Adenoma sebaceum and Tuberous sclerosis (Option B): It is incorrect since the image shows a shagreen patch and not adenoma sebaceum.

 

Neurofibroma and Neurofibromatosis (Options A) and Cafe-au-lait spots and Neurofibromatosis (Option D):

  • Neurofibromas and cafe-au-lait spots are associated with neurofibromatosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with progressive hearing loss in the right ear, occasional imbalance while walking, and a sensation of fullness in the ear. On examination, she has decreased corneal reflex on the right side. MRI of the brain is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Vestibular schwannoma

 

Explanation:

MRI Brain shows ice cream cone appearance at cerebellopontine angle. The trigeminal nerve (CN V) emerges from the lateral pons, superior and anterior to the entry of CN VIII. So in case of tumor originating from 8th nerve, the fifth nerve is compressed and causes absent corneal reflex. Root value of corneal reflex is (5,7). Cerebellar astrocytoma is ruled out based on location. 

Craniopharyngioma (IOption C): MRI reveals a suprasellar cystic and solid mass, often with calcifications. The cystic component is usually hyperintense on T2 and variable on T1, depending on protein content. Solid components enhance with contrast.

 

Prion Disease (Option D): MRI typically shows hyperintensity in the basal ganglia, thalamus (including the "hockey stick sign" in variant CJD), and cortical ribboning on diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) and FLAIR sequences, reflecting spongiform changes.

questions.text: A 9-year-old child presents with progressive dystonia, difficulty walking, and slurred speech. On examination, he has oromandibular dystonia and choreoathetosis. MRI brain shows bilateral hypointensity of the globus pallidus with a central area of hyperintensity. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Pantothenate kinase-associated neurodegeneration

 

Explanation:

Child is having parkinson like features and MRI shows bilateral hypointensity of the globus pallidus with a central area of hyperintensity.This is called eye of tiger sign and is seen in Pantothenate kinase-associated neurodegeneration (PKAN) (aka Halloverdan spatz disease). It is rare autosomal recessive neurodegenerative disorder marked by the accumulation of iron in the brain's nuclei.

HD is seen with chorea. Craniophyrangioma is seen in children and presents with raised ICP. Prion disease will present dementia and myoclonic jerks.

questions.text: Which of the following is a CT finding of Pneumocephalus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All of the above

 

Explanation:

Pneumocephalus/pneumatocele/intracranial aerocele- the presence of air in the epidural, subdural, or subarachnoid space or within the brain parenchyma or ventricular cavities.

 

CT findings:

Sign

Observation

Mount Fuji Sign

 

Seen in Tension pneumocephalus and has accumulation of air in the frontal region, Frontal lobes are separated and compressed by air under pressure, forming a shape like Mount Fuji

Air Bubble Sign

 

Small, round areas of low attenuation (dark regions) representing air pockets within cerebrospinal fluid spaces.

Peaking Sign

 

Frontal lobes are compressed toward each other, but not separated, seen in non tension pneumocephalus.

questions.text:
5 year old is having daily headaches and difficulty in copying from the board. He was found to have bitemporal hemianopia and MRI head was done. Which of the following is not correct about this condition 


{{caption_text}}

choices.text: Leading infratentorial brain tumor in children

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Leading infratentorial brain tumor in children

Explanation:

Given image is an MRI brain of craniopharyngioma. It is a beningn, supra tentorial tumor seen in children that compresses the optic chiasma and causes bitemporal hemianopia. Infratentorial beningn brain tumor in children is cerebellar astrocytoma and infratentorial malignant brain tumor is medulloblastoma. 

This tumor is derived from Rathke pouch and is cystic in nature. The wall of tumor is calcified which is why is looks heterogenous ( black inside and white on the rim). 

Pediatric presentation is called Adamantinomatous type and adult presentation is called papillomatous type.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about variant creutzfeldt-jakob disease?

choices.text: Periodic sharp wave complexes on EEG
Increased intensity in the basal ganglia
JEV-specific IgM in CSF by MAC‑ELISA

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) JEV-specific IgM in CSF by MAC‑ELISA

 

Explanation:

JEV-specific IgM in CSF by MAC‑ELISA is seen in Japanese B encephalitis. vCJD is prion disease that causes progressive neurodegeneration. usual case presentation is young person with dementia and myoclonic jerks. 

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) findings:

Electroencephalography (EEG)
  • Periodic sharp wave complexes (PSWC) (Option A ruled out)
  • These can be either lateralized in earlier stages or generalized in later stages.

MRI findings
  • Increased intensity in the basal ganglia (Option C ruled out)
  • Cortical ribboning (Option B ruled out)

questions.text:
A 35-year-old male presents to the ER after a fall, initially conscious but rapidly deteriorates following a brief lucid interval. The CT image is given below. What is the diagnosis?


{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Epidural hematoma

 

Explanation:

Given CT shows biconvex mass which is present in epidural hematoma.

 

CT findings:

Epidural hematoma

Subdural hematoma (Option C ruled out)
  • Biconvex or lens-shaped mass due to the limited ability of blood to expand within the fixed attachment of the dura to the cranial sutures
  • Does not cross suture lines.
  • Typically crescentic in configuration, extending over the cerebral convexity due to the lack of anatomical constraints in the subdural space.

 

 

Extradural Hematoma (Option B): This is synonym for epidural hematoma. While not incorrect in meaning, it is less commonly used in clinical practice, and "epidural" is the more standard term, making A the best answer.

 

Intracerebral Hematoma (Option D): Bleeding within the brain parenchyma itself, often due to hypertension or trauma. On CT, it appears as a hyperdense area within the brain tissue and is not typically associated with a lucid interval or a lens-shaped bleed.

questions.text:
Based on the MRI finding (shown below) , Which of the following criteria and corresponding treatment used in this condition?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) McDonald’s criteria, IV Steroids

 

Explanation:

  • MRI shows Dawson’s fingers, characteristic finding in Multiple Sclerosis (MS).
  • Criteria used is McDonald’s criteria and IV Methylprednisolone (Steroid) is the treatment of choice in MS.
  • Brighton criteria (Option B): Used for Gullaine barre syndrome (GBS) and treatment of choice is IVIg (Immunoglobulin).

Multiple Sclerosis:

Clinical features
  • U/L Optic neuritis: Positive Uhthoff sign (blurring of vision on heat exposure)
  • Sensory: Positive Lhermitte sign (Flexion at neck → Paraesthesia /shock-like sensation across the spine/back)

Scoring scale

Extended disability scoring scale (EDSS)

Diagnosis
  • Criteria: McDonald’s criteria (Option C)
  • MRI: Dawson’s fingers (demyelination over periventricular areas); lesions dissemination over time & space seen.
  • CSF: Oligoclonal bands +

Treatment
  • Acute: IV Methylprednisolone (Option C)
  • Disease modifying drugs: Ocrelizumab (anti-CD20) > Natalizumab >> Mitoxantrone.
  • Other drugs:
    • IFN-β: least side effects and hence more preferred in chronic disease
    • Fingolimod: SIP-1 Modulator
    • Gatiramer acetate: Polypeptide drug
    • Dimethyl fumarate: Krebs cycle metabolite
    • Miscellaneous : Daclizumab, Almetuzumab, Mitoxantrone

questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents to the ER with a sudden onset of headache and right-sided arm weakness that started while brushing his teeth in morning at 7 am. He is known case of hypertension and says he slept on couch last night while watching TV. On examination at 9 am he has irregularly irregular pulse, his arm weakness has improved significantly (power grade 4/5) and he can talk, drink water, chew food and walk normally. NCCT head is normal. Which of the following is the cause of this presentation?

choices.text: Neuronal death due to cerebral anoxia
Saturday night palsy due to neurapraxia

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cerebral embolism with spontaneous reperfusion

 

Explanation:

The patient has had spontaneous resolution of neurological symptoms in 2 hours implying transient ischemic attack. He has hypertension and atrial fibrillation as risk factors. The clot in brain was spontaneously lysed due to activity of plasmin/tissue plasminogen activation that  he escaped with mini stroke / TIA.

CT Scan brain is normal rules out any hemorrhagic event. CT can be normal in AIS in first 6 hours. 

Option A would have nuchal rigidity and CT would be abnormal. Option C will cause symptoms to persist or have neurological deterioation. Option D would occur when person fell asleep on couch with overhanging arm and would present with tingling and parasthesias as well.

questions.text:
30 year old female who delivered a male baby via C-section owing to eclampsia developed a sudden onset headache, seizures, visual disturbances and altered sensorium 2 days following delivery.BP is 180/120 mm Hg.  MRI head is shown. What is the likely diagnosis? 



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES)

Explanation:

Key finding is MRI showing hyperintensities over the occipital lobe in setting of postpartum female with history of eclampsia. Cerebral edema explains the development of sudden onset headache and other focal deficits. With aggressive BP control pateint shows significant improvement and recovers. This is seen in PRES. 

Reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome presents with sudden onset severe thunderclap headache (similar to SAH). It presents with severe new-onset hypertension. Cerebral Angiography reveals segmental narrowing and dilation of cerebral arteries (“string-of-beads” appearance), It is non-inflammatory diffuse vasccular changes that are reversible in 1-3 months. 

CADASIL (Option B): Presents in the 5th-6th decade with stroke-like symptoms (small vessel syndrome). Lack of associated features like Migraine with aura, dementia makes this diagnosis unlikely.


Postpartum transient ischemic attack (TIA) (Option C): Usually symptoms last < 1 hour (definition: < 24 hours), although sudden onset headache with altered mentation makes TIA less likely.

questions.text:
Which among the following statements is/are false regarding CADASIL ?

1) Autosomal Dominant inheritance

2) Predominantly causes Large-vessel stroke

3) Characteristic symptom is Migraine with aura

4) Notch-3 gene is involved
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) 2

 

Explanation:

CADASIL - Cerebral Autosomal Dominant Arteriopathy with Subcortical Infarcts and Leukoencephalopathy is an inherited disorder characterized by small-vessel strokes.

CADASIL (Cerebral Autosomal Dominant Arteriopathy with Subcortical Infarcts and Leukoencephalopathy)

Description
  • Inherited disorder characterized by small-vessel strokes (Statement-2)

Etio- pathogenesis
  • Notch-3 gene (Statement-4)
  • Autosomal Dominant inheritance (Statement-1)
  • Notch-3 gene regulates Epidermal growth factor (EGF)

Clinical features
  • Age: 4th-5th decade
  • Small-vessel stroke
  • Progressive dementia
  • Migraine with aura: characteristic feature (Statement-3)

Diagnosis
  • MRI: Extensive symmetric white matter changes over anterior temporal lobe

questions.text:
Child presented with reccurent TIA events. Cerebral angiography was performed. Which among the following is false regarding this condition?


{{caption_text}}

choices.text: Involves occlusion of predominantly large arteries
Can present in adults with brain hemorrhage

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Associated with vascular inflammation

Explanation:

  • Cerebral angiography shows a “Puff of smoke” appearance which is suggestive of Moyamoya disease.
  • Moyamoya disease is a rare “Non-Inflammatory” neurological disorder characterized by occlusion predominantly involving internal carotid arteries. 
  • It can present with both ischaemic - secondary to occlusion (in pediatric age group) and hemorrhagic features - secondary to burst of collaterals (in adult age group) 

Moyamoya disease 

Description

Isolated chronic, non-inflammatory (Option B) usually bilateral vasculopathy of undetermined etiology characterized by progressive narrowing of large arteries (Option A) - distal part of internal carotid artery (ICA), stem of middle cerebral (MCA) and anterior cerebral artery (ACA)

Etiology
  • Genetic: MYMY genes involved
  • Drugs: Phenylpropanolamine, Cocaine, Methamphetamine
  • Idiopathic: exact cause unknown

Pathogenesis

Chronic occlusion of large arteries leads to development of collaterals usually involving lenticulostriate branches - gives rise to “Puff of smoke” appearance on angiography.

Vascular inflammation is absent.

Clinical presentation

More commonly affects children, usually Asians and can occur in adults. 

Can present with both Ischaemic - secondary to occlusion (pediatric age group) and Hemorrhagic - secondary to burst of collaterals (adult age group) stroke-like presentation.

Diagnosis
  • Cerebral angiography: “Puff of smoke” appearance
 
  • Alternate radiological investigations:
    • MR Angiography
    • Transcranial doppler

Management

Medical Management:

  • Aspirin 50-100mg: for maintenance
  • Anticoagulation: is usually contraindicated (Option C) as risk of collaterals induced hemorrhage can occur.
 

Surgical Management:

  • Revascularization procedures usually using superficial temporal artery bypass may be beneficial.

questions.text:
A 35 year old woman presents with sudden onset headache, seizures and focal neurological deficits. BP on admission is 160/100 mm Hg.She has a history of oral contraceptive use. CECT  head is shown below. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Heparin 

Explanation:

Patient is having hypercoagulable state due to use of OCP and CT head shows empty delta sign. It indicates involvement of superior sagittal sinus where contrast outlines a triangular filling defect due to a thrombus. The obstruction of superior sagittal sinus will cause raised ICP as absorptionof CSF will be affected. The resultant cerebral edema can explain seizures She has developed cerebral venous thrombosis. Management is anticoagulation with heparin followed by warfarin. 

Cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT)

CVT is a rare condition caused by a blood clot in the cerebral veins or venous sinuses, obstructing blood flow within the brain.

Causes:

CVT can be triggered by:

  • Dehydration
  • Pregnancy
  • Behçet's disease
  • Thrombophilia
  • Hypotension
  • Oral contraceptive use
  • Local causes: Paranasal sinusitis, meningitis, subdural empyema, head and eye trauma, facial infections, otitis media, and mastoiditis.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Symptoms depend on the affected sinus and often include:
  • Raised intracranial pressure
  • Seizures
  • Focal neurological deficits

Diagnosis:

  • MR venography is the primary diagnostic tool for CVT, revealing a filling defect in the affected vein or sinus.
  • CT scan show empty delta sign. It indicates involvement of superior saggital sinus where contrast outlines a triangular filling defect due to a thrombus 

Treatment:

 
  • Anticoagulation: Heparin followed by warfarin is the main treatment, even in venous hemorrhage.
  • Endovascular Thrombolysis: May be recommended in some cases.
  • Antibiotics: Required for infections, especially when caused by Staphylococcus aureus (seen in ~10% of CVT cases, particularly in cavernous sinus thrombosis).
  • Comprehensive Management: Includes treating underlying causes and managing complications like persistent raised intracranial pressure.

 

  • Endovascular thrombolysis (Option A): Reserved for cases where anticoagulation fails or is contraindicated.
  • Oral warfarin immediately (Option C): Warfarin is used after heparin therapy, not as the initial treatment (effect takes a few days to develop so cannot be used for immediate anticoagulation, also it increases coagulation initially).
  • Blood pressure management for hypotension (Option D): Hypotension is not a common trigger for CVT and is not the primary treatment.

questions.text: As an intern in the medicine ward, you are asked to guide the nursing staff about the various supportive care measures to improve the outcome in of Acute ischemic stroke patients who are managed with thrombolysis. Which among the following will you not advise?

choices.text: Monitor vitals and place in head end elevated position
Perform urinary catheterisation for input output charting
Pneumatic compression stockings to prevent deep vein thrombosis.
Give antipyretics to patients with fever to prevent infarct expansion

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Perform urinary catheterisation for input output charting

 

Explanation: Urethral catheterization after 24 hours is not recommended due to risk of bleeding. Placing the patient in head end elevation is done in all CNS patients to managed raised ICP. anti-pyretics help in reducing infarct size. Since patient is immobilized the risk of DVT can be minimised by starting the patient on pneumatic compression stockings.

questions.text: Which of the following is a contraindication to thrombolysis in a patient with acute ischemic stroke?

choices.text: CT showing ischemic changes in > 1/3 MCA territory
CT scan showing Hyperdense MCA sign
Large Hematochezia episode 10 days ago requiring banding

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A: CT showing ischemic changes in > 1/3 MCA territory

Explanation: CT showing ischemic changes in > 1/3 of  MCA territory indicates large infarct core and increased risk of hemorrhagic transformation. Hence thromboysis is not done. 

Option B: Hyperdense MCA sign is early feature of acute ischemic stroke and needs thrombolysis 

Option C: Hematochezia requiring banding is due to hemorrhoids and not a contraindication to thrombolysis. It is large GI bleed in last 21 days due to PUD that is contraindication. 

Option D: Epistaxis can be due to finger nail trauma and responding to nasal packing is not a contraindication of thrombolysis 

Indications and contraindications for thrombolysis

Contraindications for rtPA in AIS

Conditions Increasing Bleeding Risk: Active internal bleeding, bleeding diathesis, recent head trauma (within 3 months), recent intracranial hemorrhage, major surgery in the last 14 days, gastrointestinal bleeding in the past 21 days, recent myocardial infarction. 

Uncontrolled Hypertension: Blood pressure >185/110 mmHg despite treatment increases the risk of hemorrhagic complications. 

Large Infarct Core: CT scan revealing significant edema in more than one-third of the MCA territory is contraindicated due to the risk of hemorrhage and limited benefit.

questions.text: A 58 year old T2DM male with hypertension presents to the emergency department  2 hours after developing sudden onset of right sided arm weakness and face asymetry. His blood pressure is 170/90 mmHg, and a NCCT head shows no hemorrhage. He is on metformin, metoprolol and atorvastatin. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?

choices.text: Immediate blood pressure reduction followed by Alteplase

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Thrombolysis with alteplase

Explanation:

Patient is eligible for thrombolysis for Acute ischemic stroke- CT scan shows no hemorrhage,  within window period of 4.5 hours, no bleeding diathesis and BP < 185/110 mm Hg. 

Treatment for stroke- ischemic stroke

Immediate Medical Support
  • Stabilize the patient by managing airway, breathing, and circulation (ABCs).
  • Manage blood pressure: Reduce BP if >185/110 mmHg in candidate eligible for thrombolysis. 
  • Control fever and hyperglycemia.
  • Treat cerebral edema with mannitol or hemicraniectomy if severe.

Restoring Blood Flow: Thrombolysis & Thrombectomy
  • Intravenous Thrombolysis (rtPA): Effective within 4.5 hours of symptom onset.
  • Endovascular Thrombectomy: Best for large vessel occlusions, ideally within 6 hours; can be extended up to 24 hours using advanced imaging.

Preventing Future Strokes
  • Antiplatelet Therapy:
    • Aspirin for secondary prevention, delayed 24 hours post-rtPA or given immediately if rtPA not used. 
    • Clopidogrel or ticagrelor may be combined with aspirin for short-term use.
  • Anticoagulation: Recommended for atrial fibrillation but avoided in acute stroke unless cardioembolic source is confirmed after rtPA.

questions.text:
A 50 year old male patient came to the ER with complaints of headache, blurring of vision and right sided hemiparesis for 2 hours. He is a known case of diabetes mellitus and hypertension. On examination pulse is 92/min with BP 190/110 mm Hg. What is the most appropriate statement regarding management of this patient?

 



{{caption_text}}

choices.text: Blood pressure of the patient should be reduced to <140/90 with nicardipine
The head end of the patient bed should be flat to prevent coning of the brain.
Immediate intravenous thrombolysis is recommended since the patient is in window period
Urgent lowering of BP with nicardipine followed by thrombolysis since patient is in window period

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Blood pressure of the patient should be reduced to <140/90 with nicardipine.

Explanation:

The patient is having intracerebral hemorrhage due to hypertensive crisis. Hyperdensity is noted in putamen and affecting internal capsule causing motor deficit. According to current guidelines, BP of these patients should be aggresively lowered to < 140/90 mm Hg to reduce chances of CNS bleeding.  

Thrombolysis is contraindicated in this case so option C and D are ruled out. All cases of raised ICP should be placed in head end elevation, so option A is ruled out.

questions.text: A 65 year old male presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of right sided weakness, slurred speech and facial drooping for the past 1 hour. NCCT head is normal. What is the appropriate scoring done to confirm the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C : NIHSS 

Explanation:

National institute of health stroke scale is used to confirm the diagnosis of stroke. It has 15 parameters to do a structured neurological examination with score ranging from 0 to 42. 

Score > 5 indicates need for intervention in form of either thrombolysis or thrombectomy. 

Option A is used to asses percentage of chances of stroke occurence post stroke.

Option B is used in atrial fibrillation to asses need for oral anticoagulation. Option D is done is applicable to coronary angiography and not brain assesement.

questions.text: A 70 year old woman presents to the ER with sudden-onset slurred speech and right-sided facial weakness that resolved after 90 minutes. The resident has asked you to calculate ABCD2 score. Which of the following is not a component of this score
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) History of stroke 

Explanation:

ABCD2 score is clinical tool used to predict the risk of stroke following a transient ischemic attack . It includes clinical features of stroke and not past histroy of stroke. 

It helps stratify patients into different risk categories to determine the likelihood of having a stroke in the short term (usually within 48 hours to 7 days after a TIA event. 

The score is based on five clinical parameters:

Age
  • ≥ 60 years = 1 point

Blood Pressure
  • Systolic ≥ 140 mmHg or diastolic ≥ 90 mmHg = 1 point

Clinical Features
  • Unilateral weakness = 2 points
  • Speech disturbance without weakness = 1 point

Duration of Symptoms
  • ≥ 60 minutes = 2 points
  • 10-59 minutes = 1 point

Diabetes
  • History of diabetes = 1 point

ABCD2 Score Interpretation:

< 4 points

Low risk of stroke (1% risk of stroke within 2 days)

4-5 points

Moderate risk of stroke (4% risk of stroke within 2 days)

> 5 points

High risk of stroke (8% risk of stroke within 2 days)

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man with hypertension presents to the ER  at 6 am in morning with excruciating headache and sudden onset face, arm and leg weakness. On examination GCS is 8 and blood pressure is 220/110 mmHg. NCCT head is shown. Cause of this presentation is? 



{{caption_text}}

choices.text: Rupture of penentrating arteries supplying internal capsule

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Rupture of penentrating arteries supplying internal capsule

Explanation:

This patient's presentation of a hemorrhagic stroke, with NCCT head showing hyperdensity involving Putamen. This is most commonly associated with long-standing hypertension, leading to rupture of penentrating arteries supplying the internal capsule. Option A will have nuchal rigidity. Option C is seen in setting of hypercoagulable state while our case has hypertension. Option D will cause cerebral edema involving occipital lobes.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is brought to ER with sudden onset of right-sided arm weakness and difficulty speaking.His gaze is deviated to the left, and he has a right homonymous hemianopia. Which of the following is the most likely location of the thrombus causing this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct answer-B) Left MCA, Dominant hemisphere

Explanation:

The patient presents with left MCA terrirtory stroke causing right sided arm weakness and affecting the dominant hemisphere. That explains Broca's aphasia.

In cortical stroke pateint looks to side of lesion hence pateint is looking to left. Reason is destructive lesion in left frontal eye field

Involvement of left optic radiations (MCA supplies parietal and temporal lobes) explains the right sided homonymous hemianopia 

Option C will present with Alexia without agraphia. Option D will cause spatial neglect ,map reading issues and prosopagnosia.

questions.text: 60 year old man presents with sudden onset right face deviation and arm weakness for last 8 hours. BP on admission is 185/110 mm Hg. NCCT head shows hypodensity in parietal lobe and CTA shows clot in M2 segment of MCA. Which is the best intervention for this patient?

choices.text: Lower BP with Nicardipine followed by Teneceteplase
Lower BP with Nicardipine followed by Aspirin loading 325 mg

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B: CT perfusion with endovascular thrombectomy

The clinical presentation of Acute ischemic stroke with symptoms persisting for > 6 hours. Hence CT Perfusion will be done followed by thrombectomy to remove the clot occluding M2 segment of MCA. The patient is outside the window period of thrombolysis of 4.5 hours.

Option A is done for SAH. Option C is done if thrombolysis was scheduled. Option D is wrong as aspirin is started after 24-48 hours of  admission in AIS.
